What I Have Learned

This subject focused heavily on low-level programming, which was a significant shift from my other courses. Initially, it was challenging, but as time went on, it became much more enjoyable and manageable. I gained extensive knowledge in object creation through programming, camera movements, rendering, shading, texturing, and applying lighting effects in graphical programming. Additionally, I became more conscious and aware of memory management and how to prevent memory leaks throughout this course.

Project 1 of the Course

In the first project, we learned how to program using OpenGL and CMake to create graphical boxes with textures, colors, and to simulate camera movement around the objects. When I mention "camera movement," it's actually an illusion; instead of moving the camera, we moved the objects themselves. By the end of the project, we had a chessboard with "camera" movements, multiple textured objects, and the ability to move chess pieces. You can see a demo video as a GIF to the right. If you look closely, you'll notice the textures look a bit off—and they were! I applied the textures incorrectly to both the chess pieces and the board, which caused the texture to appear distorted. However, I learned from this experience and improved on it significantly in the second project.

Disclaimer: The GIF may appear laggy due to its lower frame rate, which is a limitation of the format. If you'd like to see the video with a smoother frame rate, you can find it in the code linked below. Inside the Assignment folder, there's a video with better quality.

Project 2 of the Course

This project was a three-day exam where we were tasked with creating a Sokoban lookalike just in 3D. Sokoban is a classic puzzle game in which the player must push boxes to their correct locations in a warehouse. You can play the original 2D version of the game here.

For this project, I used the objects and knowledge from Project 1 and applied them here. It was much easier to start and build the program this time. The challenging parts were the lighting and texturing. Both issues arose because I had changed how I applied textures based on the mistakes from Project 1. In short, I had set all the objects as one with texture coordinates at (0.0), instead of treating each object separately. Additionally, since I hadn't worked with lighting in the previous project, I wasn't sure how it should look. Eventually, I managed to resolve the problems with texturing and lighting.
